p: The lessons from SARS, MERS, and Ebola tell us that early case identification is critical to protect both patients and those caring for them. In 2014, a patient presented to a Dallas emergency department after returning from Liberia with low-grade fever, abdominal pain, dizziness, nausea, and headache ( 9). The patient had Ebola. Because clinicians did not obtain the 1 potentially distinguishing clinical clue—a travel history—patient and caregiver well-being was compromised.
